dek: What our bodies do for money

stand_sit.text: Tell me a bit about your job.

body.text: What are physical requirements for your job?

environment.text: Finally, tell me about your work environment.

story.text: This circle represents an occupation that has similar physical requirements to yours. Each dot represents about 50,000 Americans who do that job.
↑ Some similar jobs pay more. ↓ Some pay less.
← These jobs on the left have very different physical demands from yours →.
In the middle is every other job in America.
A century ago, most people worked physically taxing jobs in factories or farms. But over time, American jobs became less physically demanding.

story.hl: Percent of workers, crouching is required
story.text: But many jobs in America are still physically demanding. These workers said they are required to crouch – everyone from nurses to electricians.

story.hl: Percent of workers, climbing ladders, ropes, or scaffolds is required
story.text: These workers said they are required to climb ladders, ropes, or scaffolds. It includes firefighters and janitors.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to wetness
story.text: A physical task could also mean you’re exposed to environmental hazards. This is who is exposed to wetness, like water, sewage, or bodily fluids.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to extreme heat
story.text: This is who is exposed to extreme heat from things like stoves and fires.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to outdoors
story.text: As we experience more heat waves, people who work outdoors will face increasing risks from overheating.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to hazardous contaminants
story.text: And this is who is exposed to hazardous contaminants, including mechanics and construction workers.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required less often than monthly, including never
story.text: But doing less physically demanding work doesn’t mean most people are mentally engaged. In fact, a huge portion of jobs never require problem-solving.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required once per day
story.text: In fact, a very small portion of workers report having to problem-solve daily.
But having some autonomy over our work can make even the worst job bearable. Unfortunately, many people are required to be in a certain position most of the day.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: These workers are required to stand most of the day. Research has shown prolonged standing can have serious adverse health effects.

story.hl: Percent of day where sitting is required, mean
story.text: Many workers are required to sit most of the day, which is also bad for us.

story.hl: Percent of workers, choice of sitting or standing is allowed
story.text: In fact, only a fraction of the workforce has the choice of sitting or standing when they please.

story.hl: Percent of workers, without the ability to pause work
story.text: Meanwhile, a huge portion of workers lack control over when they can take a break. They are required to work through being tired or needing to use the restroom.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with telework available
story.text: While the pandemic helped many people start working from home, only a tiny portion of workers say they can work remotely.
When I was a kid in the 1980s, my father was in school to be an engineer. For various reasons, including money, he chose to leave school.

story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: My parents tried running a dry cleaner, a car stereo store, and finally a vending machine business. They were exhausting, physically demanding jobs.

story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: One day my dad came home later after getting his hand stuck in the vending machine gears. He had to call 9-1-1 to get unstuck.
A year later, my dad chose to go back to school to be an engineer. He’s loved it ever since.
I often wonder what would’ve happened if he had no ability to escape that life—if he had no choice but to let his job erode his physical health.
